materials.raw_text: B: 20 g, O: 10 g, Pm: 8 g, Si: 30 g

sourcing.instructions: B: Boron can be sourced from chemical supply stores or online chemical suppliers. O: Oxygen can be obtained from compressed gas suppliers. Pm: Promethium can be acquired through specialized nuclear material suppliers. Si: Silicon can be found at electronics or materials supply stores.

1. Measure 20 g of boron powder using a precision scale. 2. Measure 10 g of oxygen in gaseous form (ensure proper safety protocols). 3. Measure 8 g of promethium. 4. Measure 30 g of silicon powder. 5. In a clean, dry mixing container, combine the boron, promethium, and silicon powders thoroughly using a stainless-steel spatula until uniform. 6. Slowly introduce the gaseous oxygen while mixing continuously to ensure even distribution.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixture into a suitable high-temperature furnace. 2. Heat the mixture gradually to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C per minute. 3. Maintain the temperature at 1000 °C for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and fusion of components.

steps: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool down naturally to room temperature (approximately 25 °C) over a duration of 4 hours. 2. Avoid any rapid cooling methods to prevent thermal shock.

steps: 1. Once cooled, remove the solid sample from the furnace. 2. Use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth any rough edges and achieve the desired finish. 3. Optionally, apply a sealant if needed for enhanced durability. 4. Allow the sealant to cure for the recommended time as per the manufacturer’s instructions before handling.
